The Śikṣā Guru

edited by Aditia Gunawan

Current Version: , 2022-06-22Z
Still in progress – do not quote without permission.
  • Witnesses
  • Metadata

List of Witnesses

  • A: Perpusnas, Jakarta, L 642
    • Physical Description: Gebang leaves, measuring 37.5 × 3.6 cm, brown wooden box, 23 folios, four lines. The manuscript is from Cilegon, Tarogong District, Garut (Krom 1914:72). The manuscript was copied in the village Mahapavitra (unidentified), on the western slope of a place called Kaləpasən.
  • B: Perpusnas, Jakarta, L 633
    • Physical Description: The manuscript consists of 41 gebang leaves, each measuring 22.6 × 4 cm, stored in a red wooden box, four lines per folio. The manuscript is from Tarogong, Garut (ROD 1914: 71). The pages are numbered 1–40 by the copyist, but there are some number- ing errors: 0 instead of 10 (fol. 11v), 6 instead of 16 (fol. 17v), 10 instead of 20, 30 instead of 40. In addition, among these 40 pages, there is no page 33; after page 16 the manuscript jumps to 19, back to number 17, then 18. However, the text is coherent in this arrangement.
  • C: Perpusnas, Jakarta, L 628
    • Physical Description: The manuscript of 23 gebang palm leaves, measuring 35 × 3.3 cm, each of which consists of 4 lines of writing. Most of the leaves are poorly damaged at the edges. The manuscript is wrapped in a kind of wooden box bearing the words “ms. Merbaboe”, indicating its provenance. Based on the record, it originated from Gedakan (old name of present-day Kedakan), Grabag dis- trict, Magelang, Central Java, on the northwest slope of Mount Merbabu. This manuscript comes from the gift of Mr. H. D. Levyssohn Norman, a Dutch politician who had served as secretary to the governor-general of the Dutch East Indies in 1869–1883, as well as an honorary member of the Batavian So- ciety for Arts and Sciences (BGKW) (NBG 1864: 71 and 111; 152; 240).

1.

Pure Circle of Three Bodily Domains

1.1

A:1vB:1vndah nihan(1) varahakna mami rumuhun ri saṅ sevaka dharma, katəkan kita ruməṅəkna kavivekan(2) saṅ hyaṅ dharma, mvaṅ kabyavasthānikaṅ(3) saṅ hyaṅ ajñāna, hana trikāya maṇḍala(4) pariśuddha, ṅaranya(5), inujarakən saṅ paṇḍita ri saṅ sevaka dharma, nyāpan tahan kveki(6) ulah śabda lavan ambək, yan kva(7) hana malīna(8) ri hr̥dayanta(9), ya teka prih(10) pəgəṅən, rakṣa pahayu juga ya, apan hetuniṅ(11) manəmvakən(12) sukhaduhkha halahayu.

Translation

I will first teach the servant of the dharma as follows. You will succeed in listening to the discussion of the holy dharma and the determined state of the holy gnosis. There is what is called the pure circle of three bodily domains,↓1 uttered by the teacher to the servant of the dharma. That is possibly the action, speech, and mind. If there is a feeling of loss in your heart,↓2 it is them that should be practiced and restrained. You should just guard them and fix them, for they are the causes of finding joy and sorrow, good and bad.

Notes
↑1. On the concept of trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha, see Chapter 9.XX (§Dharma and Three Bodily Domains).
↑2. The emendation of pṛdayanta into hṛdayanta is not only easily justifiable on palaeographic grounds, but also based on the connection of līna ‘feeling of lost’ with hati ‘heart’ in several OJ texts. Cf. RY 24.41: aḍā kalana līna riṅ hati.

1.2

yan pinahala ulahta, śabdanta, ambəkta(13), niyata kapaṅguhnikaṅ(14) hala denta yan maṅkana(15), yan pinahayu ulahta, A:2r śabdanta(16), ambəkta, avas kapaṅguhnikaṅ hayunta(17) yan maṅkana, ya ta(18) mataṅyan hana paribhāṣa kumvaṅ madyus-dyus(19) vvay tinəmunya kasvabhāvaniṅ(20) janma, hala tuməmu halanya, hayu tuməmu hayunya, maṅkana lvirniṅ(21) janma.

Translation

If your action, your speech and your mind are unrighteous, in that case you surely obtain the wrong. If your action, your speech, your heart are righteous, in that case it is clear that you obtain the virtue. That is why there is a proverb “Thus one repeatedly baths, the water is touched by the original nature of the human: bad meets its bad, good meets its good”.↓3 Likewise is human nature.

Notes
↑3. The water metaphor also occurs in SKK 20.2.

1.3

ndya dr̥ṣṭānta, iriki dadyanya, hala deniṅ halanya, hayu deniṅ hayunya, nihan upadyanta, hana ya maṇik anargha ṅaranya, tan kinavruhan(22) mulyanya, tan paprameya ri(23) rahayu, kaliṅanya ikaṅ maṇik anargha, lavan maṇik sarveṣṭa(24), yvagya karikāpusənta ri gaṅsa, tambaga lavan timahC:2v, aparan ta yvagyanika, niyatār A:2v mijil śrīnika lavan dhanuhnika, maṅka pva yogya(25) paṅapusanta irikaṅ maṇik anargha, paṅikətanta irikaṅ maṇik sarveṣṭa(26).

Translation

What are the illustrations with regard to the consequence of this, [namely]: bad from its bad, good from its good? As follows is your analogy:↓4 there is what is called the priceless jewel, its value can not be known, being incomparable↓5 in terms of beauty. The meaning is: the priceless jewel and the most coveted jewel. Is it fitting to be bound to bell-metal, copper, and tin by you? What is the appropriateness [of such a condition]? It is evident that if its splendor and its shine come out, then your binding for the priceless jewel and your tieing for the most coveted gem in such a manner are appropriate.

Notes
↑4. I consider the word upadyanta to be derived from Skt. upādhi ‘what is put in the place of another thing, substitute; anything that has the mere appearance, disguise, peculiarity, attribute; limitation, qualification, condition, postulate’ (OJED, s.v. upadi). In this text, it seems that this word is an equivalent of lvir, so I interpret it as ‘analogy, allusion’.
↑5. tan paprameya is denazalitation of maprameya, which is not recorded in OJED, but it seems to have the same meaning as aprameya ‘immeasurable, countless, unfathomable, incomparable, indescribable, without equal’ (OJED, s.v.).

1.4

nihan liṅnira(27) ri saṅ hyaṅ śāstra ləpas ca vuṁkunuṅ(28) ceva, adhika udika tatte(29) tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ(30), tad eva(31) nigaḍyate(32), apan(33) sinaṅguh rambut ləpas ṅaranya, vulu pasagi ṅaranya, hana vuṁkunuṁ ṅaranya(34), hana uḍika, hana tater, hana sorasa ṅaranya, ika ta kabaih yvagya karika paṅapusan ta irikaṅ(35) maṇik anargha(36), paṅikətanta irikaṅ maṇik sarveṣṭa(37), taham pih yāpusən ta ri gaṅsa tambaga lavan timah, aparan ta yvagyanika, paṅapusan ta irikaṅ maṇik anargha, paṅikəA:3rtan ta irikaṅ maṇik sarveṣṭa, nahan liṅnya(38) ri saṅ hyaṅ śāstra, ləpas ca vuṁkunuṅ ceva(39), adhika(40), uḍika(41), tater(42) tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ nu yvagyanika(43).

Translation

As follow is the word of the holy treatise: ləpas ca vuṅkunuṅ ceva, adhika udika tatte tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ, tad eva nigaḍyate.↓6 Because what is considered loose hair is square hair (? vulu pasagi); there is the uḍika, the tater, and the lice.↓7 Are all of them appropriate to be bound to the priceless jewel and chained to the most coveted jewel? No, it is not like that; they should be bound to the bell-metal, copper, and tin. Why is that appropriate? The binding to the priceless jewel, the chaining to the most coveted jewel, such is the word of the holy treatise: ləpas ca vuṅkunuṅ ceva, adhika udika tatte tatur tathya tuṅgəṅ nu yvagyanika. .

Notes
↑6. This "hybrid Sanskrit" passage could not be traced. It is clear that this passage is not entirely in Sanskrit but a mixture of Sanskrit and Old Javanese. The word ləpas means ’release’; vuṅkunuṅ only appears in pavuṅkunuṅ, recorded among the list of vatək i jro. The reading of C is buṅ kuniṅ ’yellow bamboo’ which is more understandable in meaning, although it is difficult to reconcile with the present context. The word adhika means ‘superior, eminent, excellent’, but udika is obscure; tatte (tattve?) and tathya probably convey the meaning of ‘true, truth’, and are probably attributes of tatur ‘gold’. The word tuṅgəṅ means ‘steadfast, firm, unmoved, unshaken’. The general meaning of this excerpt that I can guess based on the OJ exegesis is the statement that hair is unsuitable as the binding of a jewel.
↑7. The word sorasa is not recorded in OJED, but probably it refers to Skt. saurasa ‘a partic. insect infesting the hair’ (MW, s.v.).

1.5

hana ya mas kanaka santaṅva(44) ṅaranya, mas kanaka jātirūpa, sakati mulyanya, vrəttya(45) inapisan pituṅ apitu, matəmahan ta ya satahil i vatu(46) bratnya(47), ndya ya teka tuṅgəṅ, tan limbak(48) ləgə(49), an iC:3vnapi muvah, apan samaṅkana juga, pinakādiniṅ(50) mas kabaih, ndah ya teka yvagya rahayu paṅapusanta irikaṅ maṇik anargha, paṅikətanta irikaṅ maṇik sarveṣṭa(51).

Translation

There is what is called the glowing gold,↓8 beautiful gold; its value is one kati. The course of action↓9 will be [as follows]: it is mixed seven times seven [times],↓10 transforming into the weight of one tahil of stone. How can it be strong, not undulating, unwavering, when it is set ablaze again? For only in this way is the best quality of all the gold, and then your binding of priceless jewels and your tying of the most coveted jewel are appropriate and good.

Notes
↑8. Santaṅva is not recorded in OJED, but the Old Sundanese SMG also has santaṅva. My interpretation is based on the interchangeability of v and p of the Skt word santāpa ‘burning heat, glow, fire’ (OJED, s.v.).
↑9. vrəttya is my conjectural emendation of vrәt (AB) and vr(uḥ)nya (C). I take it as an irrealis of vṛtti ‘mode of being, nature, kind, activity, function; complex formation, compound, style of composition, mode of life, conduct; mode of being, nature.’ (OJED, s.v. wṛtti).
↑10. The word inapisan is not recorded in the OJED. It is probably an -in- form of the second base of apisan ’to be one, to be united, joined’ (OJED, s.v. pisan). However, I did not find the passive inapisan in the OJ corpus accessible to me. I do not exclude the possibility to emend it to linapisan ‘to be layered’. The following combination, pituṅ apitu, is also not found in the corpus. My translation ‘seven times seven [times]’ is tentative.

1.6

ya ta kāpusan deni gaṅsa(52) taA:3vmbaga lavan timahB:5r, tar mijil śrīnika lavan dhanuhnika, aparan(53) tar yuktinika(54), salah nija, salah karma, salah svabhava(55) ṅaranika, iva maṅkana ta saṅ hyaṅ dharma viśeṣa, sira maṇik anargha, ṅuniveh avakta, yeka maṇik sarveṣṭa ṅaranya.

Translation

It [i.e. gold] is bound with bell-metal, copper, and tin, its splendor and its shine are not coming out. What are the reasons why they are not appropriate? Wrong innate [disposition], wrong karma, wrong nature. Just so is the holy supreme dharma:↓11 it is a priceless gem. And also your body: it is the most coveted gem.

Notes
↑11. The meaning of san hyaṅ dharma viśeṣa is unclear; it probably refers to the personified holy soul since it is mentioned with avakta ‘your body’.

1.7

ndah ta yāṅkən gaṅsa tambaga lavan timah, ika tan yvagya rakətakna(56) iriB:5vkaṅ maṇik anargha, paṅikətanta irikaṅ maṇik sarveṣṭa.

Translation

Here is the analogy of bell-metal, copper, and tin: they are not appropriate to be bound to the priceless jewel, [and be] tied by you to the most coveted jewel.

1.8

nihan yaC:4r, ulah mahala, śabda tar yukti, ambək(57) magələh ri kapva kaṅ(58) janma, ṅuniveh ri saṅ paṇḍita, kaliṅanya tan yvagya kari ulah mahala, śabda tar yukti, ambək magələh, rasāA:4rkən i saṅ hyaṅ dharma, lavan rakṣa ri(59) śarīranta, ṅuniB:6rveh ri saṅ paṇḍita, taham pih(60) tar yukti ika, punaruktanikaṅ(61) kavvaṅanta, hilaṅ masihniṅ manak(62) maṅrabi, manak(63) makadaṅ mvaṅ renanta(64), ya tan vnaṅ rumakṣa ikaṅ ulah mahala śabda tar yukti ambək magələh ri kapva(65) kaṅ janma, ṅuniveh ri saṅ sādhu, ndya(66) yvagya paṅrakṣanta, ri śarīranta, yeka(67) santaṅva liṅ saṅ paṇḍita(68), kanaka santaṅva ṅaranyaB:6v, ulah rahayu, śabda rahayu, ambək rahayu, ya rakṣākəna(69) saṅ hyaṅ dharma.

Translation

They are as follows: bad actions, improper speech, and impure minds towards all humans — especially toward scholars. The meaning is: bad actions, improper speech, and a dirty mind are really not appropriate; the holy dharma shall be reflected upon; furthermore, protect [it] in your body,↓12 and even more so with respect to holy men.↓13 No, it is not proper [to have improper speech, etc.]: repeatedly your birth [arises]; one stops to desire having a child, having a wife, building a family, having relatives and a mother in law. He is unable to protect [himself] from bad actions, improper speech, a bad mind towards all humans, and especially towards ascetics. How would your protection of your body be appropriate? That is ‘the glowing’ (santaṅva) according to the scholar. It means the glowing gold: the good action, the good speech, the good heart. Those should be protected by [means of] the holy dharma.

Notes
↑12. One would expect the irrealis or imperative form in this context, so the reading could be emended to rakṣa.
↑13. Besides the term paṇḍita, which I consistently translated as ’scholar,’ we find several synonyms to denote the teacher, one of which is vvaṅ sādhu ‘holy man; saint’, as we see in this paragraph. Another word that is also used as a synonym for paṇḍita is vvaṅ atuha (equivalent to Sanskrit guru?).

1.9

nihan mataṅyan trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha ṅaranya, liṅ saṅ paṇḍita, tri ṅaraniṅ təlu, śuddha ta ya trikāya(70) maṇḍaləm, ityuktam(71), nahan(72) trikāya(73) liṅ saṅ paṇḍita.

Translation

As follows is the reason why it is called the pure circle of three bodily domains, according to the scholar: tri means three. The circle of three bodily domains is pure.↓14 So it is said. Thus are the three bodily domains, according to the scholar.

Notes
↑14. From a stylistic point of view characteristic of tutur genre, the explanation of the gloss trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha in this sentence is rather unusual. Normally, each Sanskrit term is described individually. Could it be that all manuscripts are corrupt in this passage? The description of the Old Sundanese version in SMG for the same terminology is more elaborated than that of the SiGu.

1.10

nihan(74) *təmbəynya sih saṅ paṇḍita ri saṅ sevaka dharma, pariśuddha ta ri ambək(75) rahayu, usən(76) hayva kasəlapan ambək magələh, nirmalaṁ hr̥dayam(77) citam, ndah pahaliṅlaṅ kaṅ(78) manah pvāmbək(79) tiṅət maṅaṅən-aṅən, prihən *bhikṣālakṣanam(80).

Translation

As follows is the beginning↓15 of the affection of a scholar toward the servant of the dharma. It is pure in good thought. Do it quickly! Do not be tucked in with dirty thoughts. The heart and mind are pure. Then, purify the mind and the set of your emotions! You should be aware when thinking; you should practice the activity of begging for alms (bhikṣālakṣanam)↓16 with full attention.

Notes
↑15. təmbǝy seems to be a typical OJ word in the manuscript tradition in West Java, occurring instead of the more common tambay or tambe. OS texts also have tǝmbəy. MdS only has its derived form mitəmbəyan ‘to start’.
↑16. The compound bhikṣālakṣanam is unattested in OJ and my translation, based on the understanding of lakṣaṇa in its Old Javanese sense of ‘action, doing, practice’ etc. (see OJED s.v.) is tentative. Alternatively, it may be rendered as ‘the one of mendicant (bhiksu) character’.

1.11

nihan lakṣaṇanta viku(81), hayva tr̥ṣṇa ri hulun juga, byakta taṅ raC:5rmbut pinəgatan, ya ta(82) pəgati, tan kavighāta(83) malaṅ kva hana, ya tika pariśuddha timpalakna(84) kunaṅ(85) rətakna, ya ta mas r̥kr̥t(86) masəkar *vañva ṅaranya, maṅkana ta kita masevaA:5rka *di(87) saṅ paṇḍita, hayva ta kita gumavayakna gurutalpaka(88), jagat upadrava, katakuta(89) ri sira, bhaktyānukul(90) ta kita ri saṅ guru, gavayakna kasupraṇata(91), di(92) saṅ guru, təka ri saṅ paṇḍita, dataṅ ta ri kasādhyanya.

Translation

Here are your characteristics, O holy man. Do not just be attached to servants. It is evident when the hair has been cut. Cut it [so that] there is no obstruction or hindrance. That is the purity (pariśuddha): you should cut it before and you should control it. It is what is called †r̥kr̥t† gold, and making flower offerings with water.↓17 In this manner you serve the scholar. Do not commit the sin of violating the guru’s bed (gurutalpaka),↓18 [which is] a misfortune for the world; [rather, you] should fear him. You should be devoted and submit to the teacher, you should carry out [acts of] extreme respect toward the teacher, including scholars. [In this manner you] come to the realization of that goal.

Notes
↑17. All manuscripts have vañva, unattested in OJED. I take it to be a variant of bañu. However, the irrealis form seems unnecessary. Or should it be read vaño?
↑18. The term gurutalpaka, ’the teacher’s bed’, denotes a negative behaviour: AgP 353.19 explains it as marrying (or having sex with) the teacher’s wife or the teacher’s child: gurutalpaka ṅaranya makastrī rabiniṅ guru, anakniṅ guru. In SiGu, this term is not to be confused with the more common guru talapakan, meaning the ’teacher’s foot sole’, or total devotion toward the teacher. See .

1.12

maṅkana ta kita hulun ri saṅ paṇḍita, ṅuniveh ri saṅ prabhu, tar gavayakna prabhu drohaka(93), dəṇḍana vinigraha(94), katakuta(95) ri sira, marapvan tan(96) kita na kajval(97) pati biṣama, bhaktya(98) ta kita ri saṅ(99) prabhu, mataṅyan təka ri kasādhyanya(100), maṅkana(101) ta kita rāma, kalaṅ(102), gusti, patih ri banva, kunaṅ dharma tulājñānaniṅ kadi kita, hayva ta kita tiA:5vmpaṅ svara ri byavahāra, tan paṅivakən təṅən(103) ri guṇadosa, tar yukti purihniṅ vvaṅ atuha, ujar saṅ hyaṅ āgama, hayva tutaknanta, ya ta mataṅyan tar katəkan trikāyamaṇḍalam cittam(104), nihan saṅ hyaṅ trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha ṅaranya, kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma, ya təmbəynya sih saṅ paṇḍita, ri saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

In this manner you are the servant of the scholar, and even more so of the king. Do not be unfaithful toward the king. [You] will be fined and hated. You should be afraid of him, so that you will not be sold and die horribly. You should be loyal to the king: that is why [you] come to the realization of that goal (i.e., avoiding being sold and dying). You↓19 elder (rāma), kalaṅ, gusti, vizir (patih) in the village (banva), [should behave] in this manner. Furthermore, [concerning] the quality (dharma) of a balanced mind in people like you, you should not have an unbalanced voice↓20 in the legal proceeding, do not lean left and right with respect to good and bad qualities. It is not appropriate [as the] behavior of an experienced man, says the holy scriptures. That [wrong behavior] should not be followed by you, that is the reason why [if you follow it] the three domains of body and mind (trikāya maṇḍalam cittam) are not achieved. Then the servants of the dharma should devote their full attention to what is called ‘the sacred circle of the three pure bodily domains’. It is the beginning of the affection of the scholar toward the servants of the dharma.

Notes
↑19. This implies the audience of the text involved rāma etc. Alternatively, if the word kasādhyanya indicates the fruit to be enjoyed rather than the realization of the goal of loyalty to the king, one could translate as follows: ‘You [will become] in this manner: an elder (rāma), a kalaṅ, a gusti, a vizir (patih) in the village (banva)’.
↑20. timpaṅ means ‘crippled, limp’ (OJED, s.v.). In this context of legal preceding, I interpret it as ‘unbalanced’.

2.

Ten Rules (daśaśīla)

2.1

ika hana ta(105) kapiṇḍva(106) sih(107) saṅ paṇḍita ri saṅ sevaka dharma, ya daśaśīla ṅaranya, ndya ya nihan, śrotra(108), cakṣuh, ghrāṇa, jihvā, vāk, tvak, pāṇi, pāyūpastha(109), pāda, ini(110) rəṅə̄kna saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

There is a second [type of] affection of the scholar toward the servant of the dharma, which is called the ten rules (daśaśīla).↓21 They are the following: ears, eyes, nose, tongue, mouth, skin, hands, genitals, anus, legs. This↓22 is what the servant of the dharma should hear.

Notes
↑21. About the concept of daśaśīla as a term for the ten organs, see Chapter 9.XX.
↑22. In the SiGu, the word ini, not recorded in OJED, is often used instead of nihan. This is probably an Old Sundanese influence, since this word is very frequent in Old Sundanese texts.

2.2

śrotra(111) ṅaraniṅ taliṅa, apa viṣayaniṅ taliṅa A:6r, pinakadvāraniṅ(112) maṅrəṅə̄ ikaṅ śabda hala hayu, maṅrəṅə̄(113) kita śabda manis arum(114), enak manahta, maṅrəṅə̄(115) pva kita śabda mahala, sākṣāt(116) tan kahiḍəp(117) doṣanika, tan piniṇḍvakən(118), kārya(119) hayu ri saṅ guru, ya ta kayatnakna(120) saṅ sevaka dharma, tuli maṅrəṅə̄ aji saṅ(121) viku.

Translation

Śrotra means ears. What is the sphere of the ears? They serve as a gate to hear the bad and good words. When you hear sweet and fragrant words, your heart becomes comfortable. When you hear a bad word, its fault is evidently unthinkable. Please do not repeat it. A good action for the teacher, that is what the servants of the dharma who are deaf↓23 in hearing the scriptures of the hermit should endeavor to carry out.

Notes
↑23. I wonder whether we should render tuli as tuluy ‘immediate continuation’ (see OJED s.v. tuli II: ‘see tuluy’) in this phrase. If it is the intended word, then the translation of tuli maṅrəṅə̄ aji saṅ viku would be ‘the immediate continuation of hearing the scriptures of hermits’.

2.3

cakṣuh ṅaraniṅ mata, apa visayaniṅ mata, anon ta ya(122) hala hayu, aveh sukhaduhkha, yar apa(123) ika(124) aveh sukha(125), pinakapanonta ri ulah rahayu, laṅsar kita denya, yan apa ika aveh(126) duhkha, mulata mas ri paḍanya janma len saka rika, lumaku(127) ta kita mareṅ sabhān(128), anon(129) maA:6vra kita vvaṅ(130) cheda, vuḍug, tugəl, təlihən(131), *buḍaya(132), tikəl, kəjəṅ, *kəkəṅ(133), salvirniṅ *bhīmarūpa(134) haneṅ(135) rat, ṅuniveh buta tulīniṅ panvan paṅrəṅə̄, hayva peda(136) kunaṅ yan kita(137) anvan vvaṅ *chedakṣara(138), hayva ta kita maṅkana, *caṇḍaparihāra(139) ṅaranya, apan tar kinavruhan ikaṅ *nijakarma(140), ṅuniveh vvaṅ duhkha denika(141), ya ta kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

Cakṣuh means eyes. What is the sphere of activity of the eyes? To see good and bad, which causes joy and sorrow. How could they (i.e., the eyes) cause joy? They serve as your instrument to see the good deeds. You are without hindrance↓24 by means of that. How could that bring sorrow? From them (the eyes, saka rika), you should see the gold↓25 of the other fellow human beings. You walk to a public place, you see people with disabilities, leprosy, invalidities, goiter, [a stomach affected by] starvation (? buḍaya),↓26 defolded,↓27 stiff and rigid [limbs],↓28 all kinds of frightening appearance↓29 that exist in humans, let alone those who are blind and deaf of the eyes and ears. Furthermore, do not hurt somebody who has disable bodies.↓30 You should not be like that. It is called avoiding strong emotion (caṇḍaparihāra),↓31 for the innate nature and karma↓32 are not seen. Also, people hurt because of it, that is what the servant of the dharma should pay attention to.

Notes
↑24. My interpretation of laṅsar as ‘unobstructed, without hindrance’ is based on the meaning in MdS (Hardjadibrata, 2003: s.v. langsar), which seems to be adequate with the context. In OJ the meaning is unclear, it is related with luṅsur ‘come down, slip down’.
↑25. All manuscripts contain the same reading, but the phrase mulata mas is dubious and problematic. However, the sentence mulata mas ri paḍanya janma len saka rika is problematic for several reasons. First, the phrase mulata mas is difficult to understand in this context. Second, while the sequence len saka rika occurs very often, meaning ‘other than that’, in this context, I am inclined to consider len as an attribute to janma, so janma len would mean ‘other people.’ Indeed, this phrase is rarely found in OJ, but it is attested in BY 15.16: yan movaha kita janma len kakanta. Cf. also vvaṅ len, a more common combination than janma len, occurring in Slo 30j: amaṅan ulihnya gumavayakən sakāryaniṅ vvaṅ len.
↑26. The word buḍaya is not attested in OJED. My tentative translation is based on a guess from budayut in MdS ‘having a distended stomach’.
↑27. OJED glosses tikəl as ‘broken (of something straight), broken in two, with a sharp bend or break (in a straight line), esp. of the line of the brows (when cross or angry)’. It is not clear which part of the body it refers to, but it seems to be the hand or the foot.
↑28. OJED records the word kǝkəṅ without giving the meaning. However, we find its equivalent kəṅkəṅ in OS SMG, referring as a kind of hand disease. I interpret it as ‘rigid’, synonymous with stiff, by comparing it with the MdS word jengkeng adj. ‘(unc.) stiff (like a corpse)’; ngajengkeng ‘stretched (stiff)’; jejengkengan ‘keep on stretching (of so. tormented by pain or grief)’ (Hardjadibrata, 2003: s.v. jengkeng); also with MdJ kêngkêng ‘sturdy; stiff, rigid’.
↑29. I chose bhīmarūpa ‘frightening appearance’ on the basis of the shared reading of and . Even though it is not attested in the OJ corpus at my disposal, this compound is attested in Skt sources, attributed to gods, goddess, humans, and animals. However, one would expect to have virūpa in this context, which is often mentioned along with the list of deforemd or otherwise sick people. Cf. AgP 51.29-52.12: virūpa krūra malina, akuru, atəhər agalak, puṇḍuṅ, maliṅ, kuḍisən; asiṅ vvaṅ melik iriya deniṅ hamə̄ niṅ avaknya.
↑30. chedakṣara is not recorded in OJED. I take it as a tatpurusa compound formed from cheda, in the OJ sense of ‘injured, hurt, with a defect’ (OJED, s.v.), and Sanskrit kṣara (unattested in OJED), meaning ‘the body’ (MW, s.v.).
↑31. I translate caṇḍaparihāra as ‘avoiding strong emotion’: cf. caṇḍa, Skt. ‘fierce, violent, cruel , impetuous, hot, ardent with passion, passionate, angry’; parihāra, ‘shunning, avoiding, excluding, abandoning’ (MW, s.vv.).
↑32. I take nijakarma as a dvandva compound meaning ‘innate nature and karma’. See the parallel salah nija salah karma in SiGu 1.6.

2.4

ghrāṇa ṅaraniṅ iruṅ, apa viṣayaniṅ iruṅ, pinakapaṅambuṅ ta gandha surabhi, asurabhi, *asādhāraṇa(142), surabhi(143) ṅaranya vaṅi, asurabhi ṅaranya abva lavan hapək, asādhāraṇa ṅaranya *haṅit, mataṅyan tri(144) pabhedaniṅ gaA:7rndha, aṅambuṅ pva(145) kita gandha vaṅi, enak manahta, aṅambuṅ pva(146) kita abva(147) hapək, tar enak manahta, ya mətu(148) krodhanta, ya saṅkan(149) mətu(150) śabda tar yukti(151), tan karasa ikaṅ trikāya(152) paramārtha, ya ta mataṅyan prihən kayatnakna ikaṅ viṣayaniṅ iruṅ, de saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

Grhāṇa means nose. What is the sphere of activity of the nose? It serves as an instrument to smell fragrant scents (surabhi), bad smell (asurabhi), [and] extraordinary smell (asādhāraṇa).↓33 Surabhi means fragrant, asurabhi means stinky and musty [odor], asadhāraṇa means singed smell (haṅit).↓34 Therefore, the kinds of smells are three. When you smell the fragrance, your heart is happy; when you smell a stinky and musty [odor], your heart is not happy, then↓35 your anger appears; that is the cause for the inappropriate speech to arise. The three bodily domains of ultimate truth (trikāya paramārtha)↓36 are not experienced. That is the reason why the sphere of the nose must be properly paid attention to and seriously cared after by the servants of the dharma.

Notes
↑33. asādhāraṇa is not attested in OJED. It is from Skt. ‘extraordinary’ (MW, s.v.). In this context it means ‘strong smell, extraordinary smell’.
↑34. Instead of emending haṅit to OJ asaṅit ‘with the smell of burning (singeing), burnt’, I keep the reading haṅit, and render it as a West Javanese spelling variant; Cf. MdS hangit ‘id’.
↑35. I am inclined to consider ya in ya mətu krodhanta as an emphatic or deictic particle (OJED, s.v. ya 1).
↑36. For the term trikāya paramārtha vis à vis trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha, see Chapter 9.XX.

2.5

jihvā ṅaraniṅ lidah, apa viṣayaniṅ lidah, pinakapagoṣṭhinikaṅ(153) ṣaḍrasa(154) ṅaranya, lavaṇa, kaṭuka(155), tikta(156), amla, kaṣāya, madhura, ya sinaṅguh ṣaḍrasa(157) ṅaranya, lavaṇa hasin, kaṭuka(158) *lada, tikta(159) pahit, amla hasəm, kaṣāya vuduk, madhura manis, nahan(160) sinaṅguh ṣaḍrasa ṅaranya, kabhuA:7vkti kunaṅ ika denta jənəka(161) ri sakita(162) denya, hayva ta kita maṅkana, təka kasādhyan(163) deniṅ viṣayanya, ya ta ketu(164) tumiṅgalakna(165) kārya hayu ri saṅ guru, tan karasa ikaṅ trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha yar(166) maṅkana.

Translation

Jihvā means tongue. What is the sphere of activity of the tongue? It serves as an instrument of tasting↓37 the six flavors, namely: salty (lavaṇa), spicy (kaṭuka), bitter (tikta), sour (amla), savory (kaṣāya),↓38 sweet (madhura). These are called the six flavors (ṣaḍrasa). Lavaṇa means salty, kaṭuka is spicy,↓39 tikta bitter, amla sour, kaṣāya savory, madhura sweet. Those are called the six flavors (ṣaḍrasa). Furthermore, they are all enjoyed by you; you will be oblivious of everything but becoming sick because of them. You shall not do so. Its object (i.e. the tongue) becomes a goal to be realized. That is a sign that you will abandon good works toward the teacher. If so, then the pure circle of three bodily domains is not experienced.

Notes
↑37. My emendation paṅrasanikaṅ ‘the instrument to taste’ is based on the common expression in the context of saḍṛasa. Cf. OJ exegesis on Vrh 34, in which we find paṅrasa with ṣaḍrasa: pinakapaṅrasa pakənanya yan pamukti ṣaḍrasa. Alternatively, we could probably emend to pamukti which has the same meaning.
↑38. In Sanskrit, kaṣāya means ‘astringent’, but the OJ exegesis gives vuduk as its equivalent. According to Zoetmulder, vuduk is ‘fat; also: sweet flavour’ (OJED, s.v. wuduk), I take it as savory to differentiate with sweet. Cf. Malay term gurih ‘id.’; note also the term nasi uduk, a kind of dish with rice as a basic, cooked in coconut milk and multitude of spices resulting in a very fragrant and flavorful rice.
↑39. I take the meaning of lada as ‘spicy’ from OS and MdS. In OJ it means ‘pepper’, as in Proto Malayo-Polynesian.

2.6

vāk ṅaraniṅ śabda, apa viṣayaniṅ śabda(167), tar tutakna sakojarta, vak pāruṣya, capala(168) asta(169), rika durbala masukər(170), tar paṅinakən(171) ri lokapara, kunaṅ ujaranta(172), śabda manis arum vulat manohara, salvirniṅ maṅdadyakən kaviratyanya, mvaṅ karəṅə̄ deniṅ lokapara, maṅkana ta kita rumakṣa śabda.

Translation

Vāk means words.↓40 What is the sphere of activity of the words? Not every word should be followed by you: harsh words [equal] aggressive behavior.↓41 In the situation of powerlessness and in trouble, you do not make other human beings feel at ease. However, what you should speak are words that are sweet, gentle, [with] an agreeable [facial] gesture. All kinds of things that make them indifferent to the world, and which are heard in succession by human beings,↓42 that is how you guard your words.

Notes
↑40. One would expect tutuk instead of śabda, but śabda as a definition of vāk in the context of ten organs is attested in KAS 05j ka, ikaṅ kāya, vāk, manah. kāya ṅa śarīra, solahniṅ taṅan suku, ya kāya ṅaranya. vāk ṅaranya: śabda. salvirniṅ vuvus ya śabda ṅaranya.
↑41. capala asta ‘restless hands’ seems to be out of context. In inscriptions, for example Waharu I, vāk capala and capala hasta ‘(Skt) with restless hands, rash in coming to blows, aggressive’ are listed among the sukha-duhkha ‘the vicissitudes of life’: rah katəmu riṅ havan, vākcapala, hastacapala. Should it be emended to vāk capala? Cf. Vrh 18.2: panasbaran, lobha, capala hasta, capala pāda, vākcapala... lakṣaṇaniṅ citta si rajah.
↑42. It seems that loka para is an equivalent of loka parəmpara ’uninterrupted, in succession’ (or parampara; see OJED, s.v. parampara), attested in AgP 352.21: hana ujar yogya rĕṅə̄n deniṅ loka parəmpara; Cf RY 3.3, which mentions parampara after the verb karəṅə̄: praśasta karĕṅə̄ parampara ujar narendrâpagəh. Alternatively, loka para could be considered as an equivalent of paraloka ‘other people’.

2.7

tvak ṅaraniṅ kuA:8rlit, apa(173) viṣayaniṅ kulit, *ṅarasa *ṅahiḍəp(174) panas tis, ikaṅ maṅkana, kaliṅanya, ya prah(175) pəgəṅən juga ikaṅ viṣaya mijil(176) saka(177) ri kulit.

Translation

Tvak means skin. What is the sphere of activity of the skin? To feel and experience heat and cold. The point of this is the effort to restrain the passions↓43 that emerge from the skin.

Notes
↑43. In this context, I take the meaning of viṣaya as ‘passion’ (OJED, s.v. wiṣaya 4.).

2.8

pāṇi ṅaraniṅ taṅan, apa(178) viṣayaniṅ taṅan, *masāṅguliniṅ taṅan, matalaṅkup(179) yan(180) paṅucap lavan saṅ guru, mvaṅ tan pasalaṅgapan(181) tuṅgal(182) lavan saṅ guru, ṅuniveh tan panuduh asta mukha(183) saṅ guru, tan pacumbana(184) yan gamələn taḍahən(185) saṅ guru, athava tan(186) paṅalap drabya hyaṅ saṅ guru, ṅuniveh riṅ rat kabaih, kaliṅanya, hayva paracidra(187) yar hana kahyunya(188), hanāsipattra(189) ri aji saṅ viku, nihan deyanta rumakṣa taṅan(190).

Translation

Pāṇi means hand. What is the sphere of activity of the hand? To join the fingers of the hand,↓44 to join [the hands] when talking to the teacher. Also not to join the hands together with the teacher, and especially not to point the hand toward the face of the teacher; when the food of the teacher should be grasped, it should not be touched with the mouth.↓45 Or, do not take the teacher’s divine-property (drabya hyaṅ), let alone of any [kind of] people. This means do not be disloyal↓46 if he has a request. There are “sword leaves”↓47 in the sacred texts of the hermit. Such is what you should do to guard your hands.

Notes
↑44. masaṅguliniṅ taṅan literally means ‘to make the fingers of hand as one’ or, in other words, ‘to join the fingers of hand’; masaṅguli is from aṅguli ‘(Skt) finger’, but the derivative form saṅguli and verbal form maṅguli are not recorded in OJED.
↑45. In OJED, acumbana usually means ‘making love, having sexual intercourse, united in love’, but in this context, the Sanskrit meaning ‘to kiss, to touch with the mouth’ (MW, s.v. cumb) seems more suitable.
↑46. MsC has paracidra, while MsA and MsB have palarcidra. The latter two manuscripts seem to be influenced by the Old Sundanese. Cf. SMG 2.2 hantə ṅǝnah palar cidəra ku paṅəsi huma sakalih.
↑47. The usage of the word āsipattra ‘sword leaves’ in OJ is usually used in depictions of hell. Here it seems to be an allusion to the misfortune provoked by the teacher. Compare the similar expression jagat upadrava, one of the ‘terrifying weapon’ possessed by the teacher.

2.9

pāyu ṅaraniṅ lət, apa viṣayaniṅ lət, utər(191) saṅgāṅisiṅ maṅhətut deyanta rumakṣa lət(192), tan pahətut ri harəpən saṅ guru jana(193), tan paharəpa(194) vvaṅ yan aṅisiṅ(195), tar kinvan(196)B:14r de saṅ guru, mvaṅ saṅ paramābhyāgata kabaih, nihan deyanta rumakṣa silit.

Translation

Pāyu means anus. What is the sphere of activity of the anus? It is circular (utər) and joint (saṅga). Defecating [and] farting [as appropriate] are the ways in which you guard the anus. You should not fart in front of the teacher of men, you should not be in front of people when you defecate. [These behaviors] are not ordered by the teacher, and by all the religious wanderers (paramābhyāgata).↓48 Such are the ways in which you should guard your anus.

Notes
↑48. The combination paramābhyāgata is not attested in OJED; it literally means ‘most respected guest’, which I interpret as a reference to a ‘religious wanderer’.

2.10

upastha(197) ṅaraniṅ pəlat(198), apa(199) viṣayaniṅ pəlat, ānanda aṅəyəh, nihan(200) kaliṅanya, tan paharəpakna(201) vvaṅ(202) maṅəyəh, ṅuniveh para(203) sujanma kabeh(204), lanaṅ vadvan, hulun hadyan, kaniṣṭha, madhyamottama(205), apan(206) agəṅ(207) *marurucanya(208), mətu(209) papaniṅ dadi(210) vvaṅ, apa pinakapāpanyaB:14v, anon(211) mara kita vvaṅ dinval, doṣanya ta, striA:9rsaṅgrahanya, mitradroha(212), gurudroha, muṅpaṅ rabi laraṅan, aglis āvak siki(213) tan ahayu(214) yan maṅkana(215), kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma(216).

Translation

Upastha means sexual organ. What is the sphere of activity of the sexual organ? To feel sexual pleasure [and] to urinate. The meaning is as follows: to urinate, it should not be done in front of the people, especially those of high birth: male, female, servant, noble man, low, medium, and high. Since its maruruca (?) is great, the sins of becoming a human being comes out. What is considered as its sins? You see a man that is sold. His sins are his [way of] seizing women: misbehaving toward friends, misbehaving toward the teachers, taking by force forbidden women. The body vehemently becomes dirty if it is as such. [That] must be paid attention to by the servants of the dharma.

2.11

pāda ṅaraniṅ(217) suku, apa visayaniṅ suku(218), lumaku asiṅ(219) saparanta, yar maṅalvar maṅiḍul, maṅulvan maṅetan, atava anrap ta(220) sila, kunaṅ deyanta maṅrakṣa suku, tan paḍəḍəlan, tan paṅraṅkakan(221) tan *pamagah-magahan(222), tan pamire-mire, tan paluṇḍu(223), tan *padvaṅdaṅ(224) ri harəpən saṅ guru, ri paramābhyāgata kabaih, nihan ta rumakṣa suku, kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

Pāda means the feet. What is the sphere of activity of the feet? To walk wherever is your destination, whether you go to the north, south, west, east, or to sit in a sila position. Then the way to guard the foot is: not kicking, not assuming an impolite posture,↓49 not [assuming] an unstable posture,↓50 not to lean sideways, not to lie stretched out, not sit by dangling↓51 the leg in front of the teacher, [or] of all religious wanderers. This [is the way] to guard the foot, [which] should be made the object of full attention by the servant of the dharma.

Notes
↑49. See OJED aṅraṅkak ‘to assume a bold attitude (ready for fighting)’ (OJED, s.v. raṅkak), listing one occurrence from RY 8.61: vvil kapvāṅraṅkak caṅciṅañ caṅka-caṅkag. Cf. BS 105.14–106.3 oṁ sila sila mānuṣa, sila gaṇa maheśvara, amire bhaṭāra brahmā, aṅraṅkak bhaṭāra rudra, akilusū mahādeva, aṅruṅkuk saṅ hyaṅ śaṅkara, sila pas bhaṭāra viṣṇu, atimpuh bhaṭāra śambhu, muruduṅ bhaṭāra śiva, aṅadәg i gunuṅ nāga. Can it mean ‘to crawl’ as merangkak in Malay?
↑50. The derivative form pamagah-magahan is not recorded in OJED. Its base, agah-agah, is plausibly a variant spelling from the base haga-haga ‘thoughtless, wild, uncontrollable’ (OJED, s.v.).
↑51. padvaṅdaṅ is not recorded in OJED, but the meaning from MdS dongdang, sidongdang ‘sit with both legs dangling to one side’ seems to be appropriate in the present context.

3.

Five Instructions (pañcaśikṣā)

3.1

nihan ta(225) kapintiganya sih saṅ paṇḍita, ri saṅ sevaka dharma, niA:9vhan pañcaśikṣā ṅaranya, ndya ya(226) nihan,

Translation

As follows is the third affection of the scholar to the servant of the dharma. Here are the five instructions, as they are called, namely:

[line 1 & 2] akrodho guruśuśruṣā(227), śaucam(228) āhāralāghavam apramādaś ca pañca vaite(229), niyamāḥ(230) parikīrtitāḥ(231)
Parallels
  • VS.4
  • Vhr.61

3.2

akrodho(232) ṅaranya, tar dadi ika saṅ sevaka dharma, mentonakən(233) krodhanya i harəpən saṅ guru, ṅuniveh i para sujanma(234) kabaih(235), guruśuśruṣā(236) ṅaranya, bakty anukul(237) ta kita ri saṅ guru, tar madvah ri suku saṅ matuha(238), maṅkana(239) yar hana paB:15vkvan saṅ guru, pariśuddha ta kunaṅ(240), kayatnakna(241) taṅ trikāya paramārtha, ya ulah(242) rahayu(243), śabda rahayu, ambək rahayu, advah aparək(244) kayatnakna ikaṅ trikāya maṇḍala A:10r pariśuddha(245), mvaṅ daśaśīla, pañcaśikṣā, nahan(246) kaśuśrūṣāniṅ(247) maṅguru(248) ṅaranya, śauca(249) masəhan(250) taṅan yan(251) magaməlan(252) taḍahən saṅ guru, ṅuniveh drabya hyaṅ saṅ paṇḍita, āhāralāghava(253), śīghra(254) ta kitānaḍah(255), agəṅ(256) kəpəl(257) kāmakāra(258) śīghrānaḍah, hayva ta kita maṅkana(259), ya kukṣi(260) pura ṅaranya, umapa pva deniṅ manaḍah kaliṅanya, ya ta prāṇa sadhāraṇa juga upajīvaniṅ umaṅən-aṅən(261) saṅ hyaṅ hayu, nihan pañcaśikṣā ṅaranya, kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSiksaGuru

4.

Instructions of the Dharma

4.1

nihan kapiṅpatnya(262) sih saṅ(263) paṇḍita, ri saṅ sevaka dharma, ini dharmaśikṣā ṅaranya, ndya ya, nihan ślokanya(264),

[line 1] ālekhyam(265) hasitam(266) gītam(267) jr̥mbhanam(268) ca kaṇṭhāravāñ(269) [line 2] śuddham ca phalarahasyam(270), na(271) karotu(272) gurumukhe
ṅaranya.
Translation

As follows is the fourth love of the learned master towards the servant of the law. This is what is called the instruction about the law, here it is—the śloka about it is as follows:

4.2

kaliṅanya(273), ālekhyam ṅaranya, hayvānurat-nurat ləmah, hayvānuraB:17rt salə, ṅuniveh śarīranta, yan pasevaka ri saṅ guru, apan(274) hana(275) vvaṅ sulakṣaṇa(276), agələm(277) tumulis-tulis(278) pupūnya, yan(279) paṅucap lavan saṅ guru, hasitam(280) tan paguyvan-guyvan(281), ri harəpən(282) saṅ guru, ṅuniveh abañol(283), gītam(284) tan paṅiduṅ(285), denya tan pamikvanvakən(286) kavijakṣaṇaan, yar(287) tan kinvan(288) de saṅ guru, jr̥mbhanam(289) tan paṅucap lapā(290) varəg ri harəpəA:11rn saṅ guru, kaṇṭhāravam(291), tan paṅhvab(292), akadanəm(293) tan paṅulet ri harəpən saṅ guru, sudəm phalarahasyam tan paṅucap aṅkara(294) ri harəpən saṅ guru, ṅuniveh mikvanvakən namaniṅ mañal, hila-hila maṅkana, na karotu(295) gurumukhe ṅaranya, nihan kaliṅanya(296), tar magavayakna saṅ sevaka dharma.

Translation

The meaning is: ālekhyam means, do not write on the ground, do not write on the board, let alone your body, when you serve the teacher, for those who are considered men with good characteristics never tire to write on their thighs when talking with the teacher; hasitam: not to laugh in the front of the teacher, let alone to make a joke; gītam: not to sing—by that, you do not to claim expertise, if it is not ordered by the teacher; jr̥mbhanam: not to express hunger [and] satiety in the front of the teacher; kaṇṭhāravam: not to yawn; †akadanǝm† do not stretch [and emit sounds] in front of the teacher; sudәm phalarahasyam: not to speak presumptuously in front of the teacher, let alone to pronounce the name “penis”, as such it is forbidden. What is called na karotu gurumukhe, its meaning is as follows: the servant of the law should not do [that].

4.3

nihan taB:18v dharmaśikṣā ṅaranya,

4.4

ka, śalākāñjanam(303) taA:11vn pacələkan(304) ri harəpən saṅ guru, ri harəpən *astri(305) laraṅan, suravile tan *pakrala-krala(306) yar paṅucap ṅuniveh yan pasila, tan lepana(307), tan(308) pavədakan, yan(309) baturan(310) saṅ guru, ṅuniveh mijil valaharnya(311) panti, asvāgata kunaṅ(312), dantagharsā(313), tan pasusur yan paṅucap lavan saṅ guru, adhyasta(314) tan pahyasniṅ(315) memen, agəṇḍiṅ(316) kecaka(317), hārahataḥ(318) tan pavaja savilah(319), prayāsamāgama(320), tan padələan lavan astri(321) laraṅan, ṅuniveh astri(322) saṅ guru, mava ivak sama(323) dagiṅ, tan paṅabhyāsa paṅan inum, ri harəpən saṅ guru, ya ika sinaṅguh(324) dharmaśikṣā ṅaranya, kayatnakna saṅ sevaka dharma.

The list of ten organs is based on A, B and C contain a different list, i.e., svaṭā, təvək, cakṣuḥ, jihvā, ghrāna, vāk, pāṇi, pada, pāyū, upastha. This implies to the different order on their explanations. Despite the order, both mss. generaly share the same readings in the explanation of each term, so I record every variant in the apparatus.pāyūpastha norm.

om. A
Setelah lobha, naskah B dan C mengandung uraian tentang məta. Naskah B mengandung bacaan: məta ṅaranya, AvəR̥ deniṁ su§kanya, AvərR̥ deniṁ prajñanya, AvəR̥ deniṁ gunanya, AvəR̥ deniṁ paṅavraḥnya, ya makṣarya ṅaranya; naskah C: havəR̥ ḍeniṁ sukanya, AvəR̥ ḍeniṁ prajña:na, AvəR̥ deniṁ paṅavruḥnya, havəR̥ dsubscr. eniṁ gunanya, ya mta ṅaranya. Adanya uraian ini menjadikannya menjadi 11 elemen, bukan 10 sebagaimana yang diharapkan. Alasan mengapa saya menolak elemen ini sebagai bacaan yang benar terutama karena məta muncul sebagai elemen dalam daśamala di bawah § SiGu 10.mātsarya norm.

^108. śrotra] norm., svaṭā A B, sotra C • The list of ten organs is based on A, B and C contain a different list, i.e., svaṭā, təvək, cakṣuḥ, jihvā, ghrāna, vāk, pāṇi, pada, pāyū, upastha. This implies to the different order on their explanations. Despite the order, both mss. generaly share the same readings in the explanation of each term, so I record every variant in the apparatus.

^539. ya lobha ṅaranya] B C, om. A • Setelah lobha, naskah B dan C mengandung uraian tentang məta. Naskah B mengandung bacaan: məta ṅaranya, AvəR̥ deniṁ su§kanya, AvərR̥ deniṁ prajñanya, AvəR̥ deniṁ gunanya, AvəR̥ deniṁ paṅavraḥnya, ya makṣarya ṅaranya; naskah C: havəR̥ ḍeniṁ sukanya, AvəR̥ ḍeniṁ prajña:na, AvəR̥ deniṁ paṅavruḥnya, havəR̥ dsubscr. eniṁ gunanya, ya mta ṅaranya. Adanya uraian ini menjadikannya menjadi 11 elemen, bukan 10 sebagaimana yang diharapkan. Alasan mengapa saya menolak elemen ini sebagai bacaan yang benar terutama karena məta muncul sebagai elemen dalam daśamala di bawah § SiGu 10.

Translation Notes

^1. On the concept of trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha, see Chapter 9.XX (§Dharma and Three Bodily Domains).
^2. The emendation of pṛdayanta into hṛdayanta is not only easily justifiable on palaeographic grounds, but also based on the connection of līna ‘feeling of lost’ with hati ‘heart’ in several OJ texts. Cf. RY 24.41: aḍā kalana līna riṅ hati.
^3. The water metaphor also occurs in SKK 20.2.
^4. I consider the word upadyanta to be derived from Skt. upādhi ‘what is put in the place of another thing, substitute; anything that has the mere appearance, disguise, peculiarity, attribute; limitation, qualification, condition, postulate’ (OJED, s.v. upadi). In this text, it seems that this word is an equivalent of lvir, so I interpret it as ‘analogy, allusion’.
^5. tan paprameya is denazalitation of maprameya, which is not recorded in OJED, but it seems to have the same meaning as aprameya ‘immeasurable, countless, unfathomable, incomparable, indescribable, without equal’ (OJED, s.v.).
^6. This "hybrid Sanskrit" passage could not be traced. It is clear that this passage is not entirely in Sanskrit but a mixture of Sanskrit and Old Javanese. The word ləpas means ’release’; vuṅkunuṅ only appears in pavuṅkunuṅ, recorded among the list of vatək i jro. The reading of C is buṅ kuniṅ ’yellow bamboo’ which is more understandable in meaning, although it is difficult to reconcile with the present context. The word adhika means ‘superior, eminent, excellent’, but udika is obscure; tatte (tattve?) and tathya probably convey the meaning of ‘true, truth’, and are probably attributes of tatur ‘gold’. The word tuṅgəṅ means ‘steadfast, firm, unmoved, unshaken’. The general meaning of this excerpt that I can guess based on the OJ exegesis is the statement that hair is unsuitable as the binding of a jewel.
^7. The word sorasa is not recorded in OJED, but probably it refers to Skt. saurasa ‘a partic. insect infesting the hair’ (MW, s.v.).
^8. Santaṅva is not recorded in OJED, but the Old Sundanese SMG also has santaṅva. My interpretation is based on the interchangeability of v and p of the Skt word santāpa ‘burning heat, glow, fire’ (OJED, s.v.).
^9. vrəttya is my conjectural emendation of vrәt (AB) and vr(uḥ)nya (C). I take it as an irrealis of vṛtti ‘mode of being, nature, kind, activity, function; complex formation, compound, style of composition, mode of life, conduct; mode of being, nature.’ (OJED, s.v. wṛtti).
^10. The word inapisan is not recorded in the OJED. It is probably an -in- form of the second base of apisan ’to be one, to be united, joined’ (OJED, s.v. pisan). However, I did not find the passive inapisan in the OJ corpus accessible to me. I do not exclude the possibility to emend it to linapisan ‘to be layered’. The following combination, pituṅ apitu, is also not found in the corpus. My translation ‘seven times seven [times]’ is tentative.
^11. The meaning of san hyaṅ dharma viśeṣa is unclear; it probably refers to the personified holy soul since it is mentioned with avakta ‘your body’.
^12. One would expect the irrealis or imperative form in this context, so the reading could be emended to rakṣa.
^13. Besides the term paṇḍita, which I consistently translated as ’scholar,’ we find several synonyms to denote the teacher, one of which is vvaṅ sādhu ‘holy man; saint’, as we see in this paragraph. Another word that is also used as a synonym for paṇḍita is vvaṅ atuha (equivalent to Sanskrit guru?).
^14. From a stylistic point of view characteristic of tutur genre, the explanation of the gloss trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha in this sentence is rather unusual. Normally, each Sanskrit term is described individually. Could it be that all manuscripts are corrupt in this passage? The description of the Old Sundanese version in SMG for the same terminology is more elaborated than that of the SiGu.
^15. təmbǝy seems to be a typical OJ word in the manuscript tradition in West Java, occurring instead of the more common tambay or tambe. OS texts also have tǝmbəy. MdS only has its derived form mitəmbəyan ‘to start’.
^16. The compound bhikṣālakṣanam is unattested in OJ and my translation, based on the understanding of lakṣaṇa in its Old Javanese sense of ‘action, doing, practice’ etc. (see OJED s.v.) is tentative. Alternatively, it may be rendered as ‘the one of mendicant (bhiksu) character’.
^17. All manuscripts have vañva, unattested in OJED. I take it to be a variant of bañu. However, the irrealis form seems unnecessary. Or should it be read vaño?
^18. The term gurutalpaka, ’the teacher’s bed’, denotes a negative behaviour: AgP 353.19 explains it as marrying (or having sex with) the teacher’s wife or the teacher’s child: gurutalpaka ṅaranya makastrī rabiniṅ guru, anakniṅ guru. In SiGu, this term is not to be confused with the more common guru talapakan, meaning the ’teacher’s foot sole’, or total devotion toward the teacher. See .
^19. This implies the audience of the text involved rāma etc. Alternatively, if the word kasādhyanya indicates the fruit to be enjoyed rather than the realization of the goal of loyalty to the king, one could translate as follows: ‘You [will become] in this manner: an elder (rāma), a kalaṅ, a gusti, a vizir (patih) in the village (banva)’.
^20. timpaṅ means ‘crippled, limp’ (OJED, s.v.). In this context of legal preceding, I interpret it as ‘unbalanced’.
^21. About the concept of daśaśīla as a term for the ten organs, see Chapter 9.XX.
^22. In the SiGu, the word ini, not recorded in OJED, is often used instead of nihan. This is probably an Old Sundanese influence, since this word is very frequent in Old Sundanese texts.
^23. I wonder whether we should render tuli as tuluy ‘immediate continuation’ (see OJED s.v. tuli II: ‘see tuluy’) in this phrase. If it is the intended word, then the translation of tuli maṅrəṅə̄ aji saṅ viku would be ‘the immediate continuation of hearing the scriptures of hermits’.
^24. My interpretation of laṅsar as ‘unobstructed, without hindrance’ is based on the meaning in MdS (Hardjadibrata, 2003: s.v. langsar), which seems to be adequate with the context. In OJ the meaning is unclear, it is related with luṅsur ‘come down, slip down’.
^25. All manuscripts contain the same reading, but the phrase mulata mas is dubious and problematic. However, the sentence mulata mas ri paḍanya janma len saka rika is problematic for several reasons. First, the phrase mulata mas is difficult to understand in this context. Second, while the sequence len saka rika occurs very often, meaning ‘other than that’, in this context, I am inclined to consider len as an attribute to janma, so janma len would mean ‘other people.’ Indeed, this phrase is rarely found in OJ, but it is attested in BY 15.16: yan movaha kita janma len kakanta. Cf. also vvaṅ len, a more common combination than janma len, occurring in Slo 30j: amaṅan ulihnya gumavayakən sakāryaniṅ vvaṅ len.
^26. The word buḍaya is not attested in OJED. My tentative translation is based on a guess from budayut in MdS ‘having a distended stomach’.
^27. OJED glosses tikəl as ‘broken (of something straight), broken in two, with a sharp bend or break (in a straight line), esp. of the line of the brows (when cross or angry)’. It is not clear which part of the body it refers to, but it seems to be the hand or the foot.
^28. OJED records the word kǝkəṅ without giving the meaning. However, we find its equivalent kəṅkəṅ in OS SMG, referring as a kind of hand disease. I interpret it as ‘rigid’, synonymous with stiff, by comparing it with the MdS word jengkeng adj. ‘(unc.) stiff (like a corpse)’; ngajengkeng ‘stretched (stiff)’; jejengkengan ‘keep on stretching (of so. tormented by pain or grief)’ (Hardjadibrata, 2003: s.v. jengkeng); also with MdJ kêngkêng ‘sturdy; stiff, rigid’.
^29. I chose bhīmarūpa ‘frightening appearance’ on the basis of the shared reading of and . Even though it is not attested in the OJ corpus at my disposal, this compound is attested in Skt sources, attributed to gods, goddess, humans, and animals. However, one would expect to have virūpa in this context, which is often mentioned along with the list of deforemd or otherwise sick people. Cf. AgP 51.29-52.12: virūpa krūra malina, akuru, atəhər agalak, puṇḍuṅ, maliṅ, kuḍisən; asiṅ vvaṅ melik iriya deniṅ hamə̄ niṅ avaknya.
^30. chedakṣara is not recorded in OJED. I take it as a tatpurusa compound formed from cheda, in the OJ sense of ‘injured, hurt, with a defect’ (OJED, s.v.), and Sanskrit kṣara (unattested in OJED), meaning ‘the body’ (MW, s.v.).
^31. I translate caṇḍaparihāra as ‘avoiding strong emotion’: cf. caṇḍa, Skt. ‘fierce, violent, cruel , impetuous, hot, ardent with passion, passionate, angry’; parihāra, ‘shunning, avoiding, excluding, abandoning’ (MW, s.vv.).
^32. I take nijakarma as a dvandva compound meaning ‘innate nature and karma’. See the parallel salah nija salah karma in SiGu 1.6.
^33. asādhāraṇa is not attested in OJED. It is from Skt. ‘extraordinary’ (MW, s.v.). In this context it means ‘strong smell, extraordinary smell’.
^34. Instead of emending haṅit to OJ asaṅit ‘with the smell of burning (singeing), burnt’, I keep the reading haṅit, and render it as a West Javanese spelling variant; Cf. MdS hangit ‘id’.
^35. I am inclined to consider ya in ya mətu krodhanta as an emphatic or deictic particle (OJED, s.v. ya 1).
^36. For the term trikāya paramārtha vis à vis trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha, see Chapter 9.XX.
^37. My emendation paṅrasanikaṅ ‘the instrument to taste’ is based on the common expression in the context of saḍṛasa. Cf. OJ exegesis on Vrh 34, in which we find paṅrasa with ṣaḍrasa: pinakapaṅrasa pakənanya yan pamukti ṣaḍrasa. Alternatively, we could probably emend to pamukti which has the same meaning.
^38. In Sanskrit, kaṣāya means ‘astringent’, but the OJ exegesis gives vuduk as its equivalent. According to Zoetmulder, vuduk is ‘fat; also: sweet flavour’ (OJED, s.v. wuduk), I take it as savory to differentiate with sweet. Cf. Malay term gurih ‘id.’; note also the term nasi uduk, a kind of dish with rice as a basic, cooked in coconut milk and multitude of spices resulting in a very fragrant and flavorful rice.
^39. I take the meaning of lada as ‘spicy’ from OS and MdS. In OJ it means ‘pepper’, as in Proto Malayo-Polynesian.
^40. One would expect tutuk instead of śabda, but śabda as a definition of vāk in the context of ten organs is attested in KAS 05j ka, ikaṅ kāya, vāk, manah. kāya ṅa śarīra, solahniṅ taṅan suku, ya kāya ṅaranya. vāk ṅaranya: śabda. salvirniṅ vuvus ya śabda ṅaranya.
^41. capala asta ‘restless hands’ seems to be out of context. In inscriptions, for example Waharu I, vāk capala and capala hasta ‘(Skt) with restless hands, rash in coming to blows, aggressive’ are listed among the sukha-duhkha ‘the vicissitudes of life’: rah katəmu riṅ havan, vākcapala, hastacapala. Should it be emended to vāk capala? Cf. Vrh 18.2: panasbaran, lobha, capala hasta, capala pāda, vākcapala... lakṣaṇaniṅ citta si rajah.
^42. It seems that loka para is an equivalent of loka parəmpara ’uninterrupted, in succession’ (or parampara; see OJED, s.v. parampara), attested in AgP 352.21: hana ujar yogya rĕṅə̄n deniṅ loka parəmpara; Cf RY 3.3, which mentions parampara after the verb karəṅə̄: praśasta karĕṅə̄ parampara ujar narendrâpagəh. Alternatively, loka para could be considered as an equivalent of paraloka ‘other people’.
^43. In this context, I take the meaning of viṣaya as ‘passion’ (OJED, s.v. wiṣaya 4.).
^44. masaṅguliniṅ taṅan literally means ‘to make the fingers of hand as one’ or, in other words, ‘to join the fingers of hand’; masaṅguli is from aṅguli ‘(Skt) finger’, but the derivative form saṅguli and verbal form maṅguli are not recorded in OJED.
^45. In OJED, acumbana usually means ‘making love, having sexual intercourse, united in love’, but in this context, the Sanskrit meaning ‘to kiss, to touch with the mouth’ (MW, s.v. cumb) seems more suitable.
^46. MsC has paracidra, while MsA and MsB have palarcidra. The latter two manuscripts seem to be influenced by the Old Sundanese. Cf. SMG 2.2 hantə ṅǝnah palar cidəra ku paṅəsi huma sakalih.
^47. The usage of the word āsipattra ‘sword leaves’ in OJ is usually used in depictions of hell. Here it seems to be an allusion to the misfortune provoked by the teacher. Compare the similar expression jagat upadrava, one of the ‘terrifying weapon’ possessed by the teacher.
^48. The combination paramābhyāgata is not attested in OJED; it literally means ‘most respected guest’, which I interpret as a reference to a ‘religious wanderer’.
^49. See OJED aṅraṅkak ‘to assume a bold attitude (ready for fighting)’ (OJED, s.v. raṅkak), listing one occurrence from RY 8.61: vvil kapvāṅraṅkak caṅciṅañ caṅka-caṅkag. Cf. BS 105.14–106.3 oṁ sila sila mānuṣa, sila gaṇa maheśvara, amire bhaṭāra brahmā, aṅraṅkak bhaṭāra rudra, akilusū mahādeva, aṅruṅkuk saṅ hyaṅ śaṅkara, sila pas bhaṭāra viṣṇu, atimpuh bhaṭāra śambhu, muruduṅ bhaṭāra śiva, aṅadәg i gunuṅ nāga. Can it mean ‘to crawl’ as merangkak in Malay?
^50. The derivative form pamagah-magahan is not recorded in OJED. Its base, agah-agah, is plausibly a variant spelling from the base haga-haga ‘thoughtless, wild, uncontrollable’ (OJED, s.v.).
^51. padvaṅdaṅ is not recorded in OJED, but the meaning from MdS dongdang, sidongdang ‘sit with both legs dangling to one side’ seems to be appropriate in the present context.
